channel.title: Compliance
channel.description: Updated Compliance content from the US Environmental Protection Agency

item.title: Industrial User Inspection and Sampling Manual for Publicly Owned Treatment Works
item.description:
This guidance document is intended for use by Publicly Owned Treatment Works (POTW) inspectors where the POTW has an approved pretreatment program.

  • Industrial User Inspection and Sampling Manual for POTWs (PDF)(193 pp, 6 MB, January 2017, EPA-831-B-17-001)
item.dc:creator: jmayo

item.title: Toxic Substances Compliance Monitoring Grant Guidance For Fiscal Year 2017
item.description:
Currently there are two separate grant guidance documents associated with EPA’s TSCA state and tribal assistance grants, one from Office of Compliance (OC) and one from Office of Pollution, Prevention, and Toxics (OPPT). The OC funds must be used for compliance and enforcement activities. OPPT funds must be used for the development and implementation of lead-based paint programs.

This Toxic Substances Compliance Monitoring Grant Guidance covers the following topics:

  • Law and EPA policy governing Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA) grants to states and tribes,
  • Applicant submission requirements,
  • Activities that can be funded,
  • Minimum expectations for program implementation;
  • State/tribal responsibilities concerning grant accountability, and
  • Regional responsibilities concerning grant accountability.

This document provides guidance for use by EPA regional offices in negotiating and managing state and tribal grants under TSCA to conduct compliance assurance and enforcement activities.

The TSCA Section 404(g) Lead-Based Paint Programs State, Territory, District of Columbia, Tribal and Federal Grant Guidance for FY17/18 (OPPT):

  • describes the purposes of this grant program and EPA’s authority for issuing them,
  • explains what entities are eligible to apply for grants,
  • outlines what activities can be funded,
  • explains how the funds will be awarded and distributed, including the criteria EPA will consider when evaluating grant proposals,
  • discusses grant application submission requirements, and
  • summarizes grant reporting requirements.
  • Toxic Substances Compliance Monitoring Grant Guidance for Fiscal Year 2017 (OC) (PDF)(17 pp, 830 K)
  • TSCA Section 404(g) Lead-Based Paint Programs STAG Grant Guidance for FY17 (OPPT) (PDF)(18 pp, 158 K, October 2016)
item.dc:creator: jmayo

item.title: Worker Protection Standard PIRT - April 24-27, 2017 (Portland, OR)
item.description:
Objective:  To present the many facets of the WPS revisions including the definition changes, exemptions, exceptions, protection from application drift, worker and handler training, respirator requirements, HAZCOM, and mitigation measures. We will also cover special topics, including droplet size determinations, OSHA 1910.134 requirements, and other related topics.

Date:  April 24-27, 2017

Time:  Class will begin on April 24th at 8:00 am and end on April 27th by 12:00 pm

Location:  Courtyard Marriott Portland City Center in Portland, Oregon

Target Audience: New or experienced pesticide inspectors who have not attended PIRT training in the last two years

  • WPS PIRT Course Invitation Letter (PDF)(2 pp, 351 K, 12/21/16)
  • WPS PIRT Course EPA Invitation Letter (PDF)(2 pp, 362 K, 12/21/16)
  • WPS PIRT Course Agenda (PDF)(3 pp, 178 K, 12/21/16)
item.dc:creator: jmayo

item.title: Article: Next Generation Compliance: Using Advanced Monitoring Technology to Meet Today’s Challenges and Plan for the Future
item.description:
EPA and its partners are taking advantage of new tools, technologies and innovative approaches to meet new challenges with innovation to achieve the intended human health and environmental benefits of regulations and permits.  Next Generation Compliance brings the best thinking on how to structure regulations and permits combined with new monitoring and information technology, expanded transparency, and innovative enforcement to enable us to increase the effectiveness and reach of traditional enforcement.  The fast-evolving pace of environmental monitoring technology development makes advanced monitoring one of the most dynamic and promising parts of Next Generation Compliance.  Advanced monitoring technology, especially when connected with Internet or cellphone communications technology, has the power to transform how we are able to see, communicate about, and react to pollution to protect human health and the environment.

The article, Next Generation Compliance:  Using Advanced Monitoring Technology to Meet Today’s Challenges and Plan for the Future, is republished from a Special Report on Next Generation Compliance (PDF) Exit published by the International Network for Environmental Compliance and Enforcement in January, 2015.

  • Next Generation Compliance: Using Advanced Monitoring Technology to Meet Today’s Challenges and Plan for the Future article from INECE Special Report (PDF)(4 pp, 190 K, January 2015)
item.dc:creator: jmayo

item.title: Article: Advanced Monitoring Technology: Opportunities and Challenges. A Path Forward for EPA, States, and Tribes.
item.description:
Advanced Monitoring Technology:  Opportunities and Challenges.  A Path Forward for EPA, States, and Tribes notes that new advanced monitoring technology presents a tremendous opportunity for improving our understanding of environmental conditions, ensuring environmental compliance, and for effective environmental management at regulated facilities.  At the same time, whether used by citizens or agencies, new technologies also create challenges relating to data accuracy and interpretation.  Furthermore, data standards must be developed to allow for more accurate use of data from these technologies.  This article describes how EPA and state and tribal agencies are working together under E-Enterprise for the Environment to address these challenges, in five ways:  

  1. evaluating the feasibility of an independent third-party program to evaluate new sensors;
  2. developing a process to rapidly assess appropriateness of new technologies for specific purposes;
  3. developing context and helping users better understand data from new technologies;
  4. developing uniform data standards, including metadata and data quality descriptions, for data transmission so users can better understand how data was gathered; and
  5. simplifying the regulatory approval process for new monitoring methods

The article, Advanced Monitoring Technology:  Opportunities and Challenges.  A Path Forward for EPA, States, and Tribes, is republished from the November 2016 issue of EM Magazine, a copyrighted publication of the Air & Waste Management Association. Exit

  • Advanced Monitoring Technology: Opportunities and Challenges. A Path Forward for EPA, States, and Tribes (PDF)(6 pp, 622 K)
item.dc:creator: jmayo

item.title: How-to Guides and Instructional Videos for Electronic Reporting for Pesticide Establishments
item.description:
This page contains detailed How-to Guides and Videos on CDX registration, registering new establishments (Form 3540-8) and submitting annual reports (Form 3540-16) electronically utilizing EPA’s Section Seven Tracking System (SSTS) e-filing system. This page will be updated to be your main source for the most up-to-date instructional electronic reporting material.

Webinars:

  • How to Register for CDX for New Users or Add SSTS to Existing CDX Users
  • How to Use CDX to Submit EPA Form 3540-16 Pesticide Report for Pesticide-Producing and Device-Producing Establishments
  • Registering for CDX (PDF)(89 pp, 4 MB)
  • Register New Establishments Electronically (EPA Form 3540-8) (PDF)(11 pp, 733 K)
  • Submit Annual Production Reports Electronically (EPA Form 3540-16) (PDF)(21 pp, 1 MB)

item.title: Article: Next Generation Compliance: EPA embraces technology and transparency to promote compliance with environmental laws
item.description:
Next Generation Compliance is transforming how EPA, states, and regulated entities approach environmental compliance.  The five components of Next Gen provide principles and tools that can help regulated entities identify and fix pollution problems before they become violations and increase compliance by helping inform facilities, communities, and the government about environmental performance.  Next Gen can dramatically change the future by embracing new technologies and best practices in EPA’s rule development, implementation, compliance, and enforcement activities.  The article highlights some key examples of how this is happening in rules and settlements.

The article, Next Generation Compliance:  EPA embraces technology and transparency to promote compliance with environmental laws, is republished from Trends, July-August, 2016, Volume 47, Number 6, published by the American Bar Association. 

  • Next Generation Compliance: EPA embraces technology and transparency to promote compliance with environmental laws (PDF)(3 pp, 64 K, August 2016)
item.dc:creator: jmayo
